so_26830677: # Put the shuf outputs in two separate files:

shuf -n "$1" "$2" > shuf_users
shuf -n "$1" "$2" > shuf_pages

# paste the two:
paste -d ' ' shuf_users shuf_pages | sed 's/^/L /'
paste -d ' ' shuf_pages shuf_users | sed 's/^/U /'

so_16696714: echo ".."|xargs -n1 |shuf|paste -d' ' -s

the jumped quick dogs. brown over lazy fox The

su_1498979: open "$(find . -type f | shuf -n1)"

find . -type f -print0 | shuf -z -n1

open "$(find . -type f ! -name "not this file" | shuf -n1)"

Explanations about Options.-name:
This option is supported, but POSIX conformance depends on the POSIX conformance of
 the system's fnmatch(3) library function. As of findutils-4.2.2, shell
 metacharacters (`*', `?' or `[]' for example) will match a leading `.', because
 IEEE PASC interpretation 126 requires this. This is a change from previous
 versions of findutils.

so_24165017: printlinesof() {
    # $1 is filename or - for stdin
    # $2,... are the lines to print
    local i array file=$1
    [[ $file = - ]] && file=/dev/stdin
    mapfile -t -O 1 array < "$file" || return 1
    shift
    for i; do printf '%s\n' "${array[i]}"; done
}

Top-3 Similar Questions: so_24165017: Easy way of selecting certain lines from a file in a certain order
so_701505: Best way to choose a random file from a directory in a shell script
so_1320955: how to read each line from a .dat file in unix?
Top-3 Scripts:
so_24165017: printf '%s\n' "${array[4]}" "${array[2]}" "${array[9]}" "${array[5]}"

printf '%s\n' "${array[5]}" "${array[3]}" "${array[10]}" "${array[6]}"

printlines() {
    local i
    for i; do printf '%s\n' "${array[i]}"; done
}

printlinesof() {
    # $1 is filename
    # $2,... are the lines to print
    local i array
    mapfile -t -O 1 array < "$1" || return 1
    shift
    for i; do printf '%s\n' "${array[i]}"; done
}

printlinesof() {
    # $1 is filename or - for stdin
    # $2,... are the lines to print
    local i array file=$1
    [[ $file = - ]] && file=/dev/stdin
    mapfile -t -O 1 array < "$file" || return 1
    shift
    for i; do printf '%s\n' "${array[i]}"; done
}

printf '%s\n' {a..z} | printlinesof - 5 3 10 6

so_701505: files=(/my/dir/*)
printf "%s\n" "${files[RANDOM % ${#files[@]}]}"

so_1320955: awk '{printf "%s,",$0}' <oldfile >newfile

awk 'BEGIN {s=""} {printf "%s%s",s,$0;s=","}' <oldfile >newfile

str=$(awk 'BEGIN {s=""} {printf "%s%s",s,$0;s=","}' <oldfile)

lseek(0, 0, SEEK_CUR)                   = 0
read(0, "1628689\n", 128)               = 8

Explanations about Options.-e:
Perform a full hexadecimal and ASCII dump of all the data written to file
 descriptors listed in the specified set. For example, to see all output
 activity on file descriptors 3 and 5 use -e write=3,5. Note that this is
 independent from the normal tracing of the write(2) system call which is
 controlled by the option -e trace=write.

Top-3 Similar Questions: so_24165017: Easy way of selecting certain lines from a file in a certain order
so_37790318: Read line by line from parameter file in function
Top-3 Scripts:
so_24165017: printlines() {
    local i
    for i; do printf '%s\n' "${array[i]}"; done
}

printlinesof() {
    # $1 is filename
    # $2,... are the lines to print
    local i array
    mapfile -t -O 1 array < "$1" || return 1
    shift
    for i; do printf '%s\n' "${array[i]}"; done
}

printlinesof() {
    # $1 is filename or - for stdin
    # $2,... are the lines to print
    local i array file=$1
    [[ $file = - ]] && file=/dev/stdin
    mapfile -t -O 1 array < "$file" || return 1
    shift
    for i; do printf '%s\n' "${array[i]}"; done
}
